title: Listening to Your Inner Voice With Sickle Cell Disease

content: Every single person who is born on this earth is born for a reason. Your life has a purpose. Your journey is unique. Your words are powerful. And your story is meant to be told.  When you are born with or diagnosed with a chronic disease, your internal voice becomes louder in your head.  You know what you’re thinking and why you make your decisions, but your words and actions might not necessarily be clear to those around you.  And, truth be told, they don’t always have to be.

Let me be very clear. It’s not your responsibility in life to make others understand you or your pain. It’s not your responsibility to cater to those around you, to the extent that you ignore your health and your inner voice. When you have a chronic disease, you can absolutely love your family, friends, and loved ones while simultaneously taking care of yourself. The trouble comes when you ignore your inner needs in order to cater to the wants and needs of others around you. You have to find your inner voice and learn how to translate the internal dialogue that you have with yourself to those in your external environment.

content: When you are constantly living in pain, the last thing you want to do is be sick, sit down, and be immobile and pumped full of medicine. The crazy thing is that there are times when that is exactly what you need to do. You need to sit down, listen to your body, rest, and take your medicine.  For me, my internal voice would always start out gentle. I would get this small feeling that I needed to slow down, hydrate, and take my pain medication. However, I would ignore the crap out of that and go from 0 to 100.

In my head, I thought that if I slowed down and stopped, I was quitting.  I thought that I was forgetting my ultimate objective and throwing in the towel. I didn’t realize that life was a marathon, not a sprint. In a marathon, you have to pace yourself, taking the necessary breaks in order to finish your race. In a sprint, you are running like heck until you get to a “finish line,” and then you crash.

content: There would be moments for me when there was some pivotal event happening for myself or a loved one, and I would do everything in my power to ignore my inner voice telling me to stop and rest. I wouldn’t want to miss anything because I didn’t want to be what I deemed as selfish.  I didn’t want my loved ones to think that I didn’t love them and wanted to be there for them to celebrate their successes, so I would push myself. I would ignore my inner voice that was once whispering to me to slow down. Metaphorically speaking, I would plug my ears and hum, ignoring the boisterous voice in my head demanding that I slow down before I crash.  Wouldn’t you know it that every single time I ignored that internal whisper, I would internally hear the shouts of “I told you so” when I would end up in the hospital in a world of pain.

content: I say this to say that there is absolutely nothing wrong with pushing forward and ignoring doubts and negativity sometimes. However, you have to differentiate fear from fantasy.  You have to prioritize listening to yourself and your inner voice. Once you do, you will find that you have more and more control over your life. You will find that you prioritize your health and your sanity and you will be able to fully function. Also, in listening to your internal voice, you will realize the people and things in your life that don’t serve any real purpose in your life.  And when you truly trust yourself, you will let go of the people and things that don’t serve you.

In life, there is nothing wrong with taking care of yourself and putting yourself first. When your health is impacted and those around you are affected by what is going on with you, the best thing you can do is be the best version of yourself for yourself and focus on listening to your body. Your health is your wealth. You can enjoy people, places, and things a lot more when you know yourself and love yourself enough to know to listen to your body. Trust yourself.

content: Life will continue to happen all around you and that is OK. As long as you stop and take care of yourself first, everything and everybody else will fall in line.

Most of the time, when I would go through a sickle cell pain crisis, I could see that it was coming from a mile away.  My body would give me clues (meaning I was in a certain degree of pain that was not subsiding with the medication). My mind would start preparing itself for battle (like going to the hospital and fighting for my life). And my internal voice would be mentally and emotionally exhausted prior to my vocalizing to my family that I was in the worst pain of my life and needed to be taken to the hospital ASAP. Life always felt like a battle, and I always felt like I was fighting. By the time I mentally validated that once-silent voice telling me that I needed to go to the hospital, I was already mentally drained and upset with myself for my treatment of myself.

content: Physically, I always presented myself as someone who had her stuff together. I was always strong, goal-oriented, and a real go-getter. However, mentally, I wasn’t always as strong as I came across. I would teeter-totter between listening to myself and my body, completely overriding my internal voice because I put this imaginary pressure on myself to live for those around me to a certain extent.

That wasn’t healthy and that type of thinking was not sustainable. Luckily, I had a very supportive family that knew me and loved me enough to talk to me. They encouraged me to vocalize what I was feeling when I was in those critical dark moments. There were a few here and there (especially when I started getting really sick). My family encouraged me to find a therapist whom I connected with. And that angel helped me cut through all the negativity and focus on the positive. She helped me focus on the things that I can change, the things that I could fix, and the things that were in my control. She helped me hear my voice clearer and stop the negative self-talk and self-deprecating behavior. With the help of my therapist, I learned to focus on fixing the things that I can and letting God handle what I couldn’t.

content: All the thoughts, feelings, and opinions I had came from a real place. A place of fear. A fear of the unknown. A place of darkness and a lack of control over my life, thanks to a disease that is completely invisible to the naked eye. All my feelings came from a real place inside of me and all of my feelings were valid in that moment. When you have a chronic disease, the best thing you can do for yourself is to surround yourself with uplifting, positive, like-minded, focused individuals.

Try your darndest to have a positive attitude and keep as much negativity away from you as humanly possible. You have enough to worry about in life. You don’t need any help with that. You need to surround yourself with an extra protective layer of armor. Guard your mind, guard your tongue, guard your environment, and guard your peace. Listen to yourself and love yourself. And, if there is anyone or anything in your life that is trying to take you down, cut them loose. Let them go. Listen to your inner voice and prioritize yourself over others. If the things in your life aren’t adding value, then you need to subtract them and multiply peace.
